title: How to Add Vinegar to Laundry

steps.title: Keep your clothes clean with vinegar.
steps.content: Keep your clothes clean with vinegar. Pour 1/2 cup of distilled white vinegar into your washing machine instead of the detergent you usually use. This method will clean your clothes without the harsh chemicals found in many commercial laundry detergents.

steps.title: Use vinegar as a fabric softener.
steps.content: Use vinegar as a fabric softener . Prepare 1 cup of white distilled vinegar. When the laundry reaches its final rinse cycle, pour the vinegar into the washer. This will act as a simple and effective natural fabric softener.

steps.title: Pre-treat stains with vinegar.
steps.content: Pre-treat stains with vinegar. Dilute 1/2 cup of vinegar in a gallon of water. Apply this solution directly to stains on your fabrics using a clean cloth or by pouring it directly on the stain. Wash your clothes as you normally would. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Bleach clothes with a vinegar solution.
steps.content: Bleach clothes with a vinegar solution. Mix 1/4 cup of lemon juice, 1/4 cup of borax, and 1/2 cup of vinegar. Use this mixture as a gentle alternative to bleach whenever you do laundry. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use vinegar to deodorize clothes.
steps.content: Use vinegar to deodorize clothes . Add 1/2 to 1 cup of vinegar directly to the washer during the final rinse cycle if your clothes are smelly. This will eliminate odors without leaving a vinegar scent. [3] X Research source

steps.title: To stop colors from fading, pour 1/2 cup of white distilled vinegar into a load of laundry to protect the colors.
steps.content: To stop colors from fading, pour 1/2 cup of white distilled vinegar into a load of laundry to protect the colors. This technique will also prevent dark colors, such as black and navy blue, from becoming dull due to repeated washing. You can also re-treat fabrics with vinegar to keep their colors fast. Add 1/2 cup vinegar to one gallon of water. Dip bright colors in the solution to keep colors from running, then wash them.

steps.title: Prevent static
steps.content: Prevent static and lint . Add 1/2 cup of white distilled vinegar to the last rinse cycle of a load of laundry. This will prevent the static that can make your clothes annoyingly stick to other clothing or your body. For many fabrics, it can also help prevent the buildup of lint. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Remove buildup on clothes.
steps.content: Remove buildup on clothes. Regular detergents can cause soapy residue to accumulate on clothes, leading to streaks or roughness. Add 1 cup of vinegar to a gallon of water. Soak your clothes in this solution, and then wash them. [5] X Research source The buildup will be removed. [6] X Research source This residue is particularly noticeable in whites, which can become yellowed over time. Black Clothing will also appear to fade over time. Soaking them in a vinegar and water solution can reverse these effects.

steps.title: Clean your washing machine
steps.content: Clean your washing machine . Soapy residue can also build up inside your washing machine, eventually getting on your clothes. Once a month, put 1 cup of vinegar into your washer and run it without loading any clothes. This will remove the residue from the machine's tub. [7] X Research source
